sen.j: 結城 親光（ゆうき ちかみつ、生年不詳 - 1336年2月23日（延元元年/建武 (日本)3年1月11日 (旧暦)））は、鎌倉時代から南北朝時代 (日本)の武将である。
sen.e: Chikamitsu YUKI (the year of birth unknown - February 23, 1336 (January 11, 1337 in old calendar)) was a (Japanese) warlord who lived from the Kamakura period to the Nanbokucho period (the period of the Northern and Southern Courts).
Chikamitsu YUKI (year of birth unknown - March 2, 1336) was a busho (Japanese military commander) who lived from the Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

sen.j: 1331年（元弘元年）の元弘の変で、鎌倉幕府方として楠木正成が篭城する河内国の下赤坂城（大阪府南河内郡千早赤阪村）攻めに従軍するが、後に足利尊氏に属して京都の六波羅探題攻めに参加している。
sen.e: During the Genko Incident which took place in 1331, Chikamitsu YUKI joined the army of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) so as to attack Shimoakasaka-jo Castle of Kawachi Province (present-day Chihayaakasaka-mura village, Minamikawachi District, Osaka Prefecture) when Masashige KUSUNOKI had taken refuge in the same castle, but later, Chikamitsu was to change the side and joined Takauji ASHIKAGA to attack the Rokuhara Tandai (the office of shogunal deputy in Kyoto placed by the Kamakura bakufu).

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府滅亡後の建武の新政では恩賞方、雑訴決断所の役人に任じられる。
sen.e: Under the Kenmu no Shinsei (Kenmu Restoration) following the fall of the Kamakura bakufu, Chikamitsu was appointed officer of the Onshogata (the Reward Office which was the administrative organ of the Kenmu Regime, responsible for granting military awards called 'onsho') and the Zasso ketsudansho (the Miscellaneous Claims Court which was the central judicial organ of the Kenmu Regime.)

sen.j: 足利尊氏が新政から離反し、箱根・竹ノ下の戦いで官軍を破って入京すると、親光は尊氏を暗殺するため偽って降伏する。
sen.e: When Takauji ASHIKAGA, who had turned against the Kenmu Regime, made his way to Kyoto by defeating the Imperial army at the Battle of Hakone and Takenoshita, Chikamitsu surrendered on purpose so as to assassinate Takauji.

sen.j: 『太平記』によれば、親光は応対した大友貞載に、降参人のくせになぜ鎧を脱がないと言われ、尊氏暗殺の企てを見破られたと思い、せめて敵将の1人でも討ち取ろうと貞載を斬殺し、群がってきた足利兵を手当たり次第に斬り倒すも足利兵により殺されたとする。
sen.e: "The Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace, a Japanese military epic written in the late fourteenth century) shows this episode of Chikamitsu's intentional surrender as follows: Chikamitsu was ushered in by Sadanori OTOMO, who then urged Chikamitsu to undress his armor in the manner of a surrenderer, only to be murdered by Chikamitsu, who feared that Sadanori might have noticed a plot to assassinate Takauji and rashly turned offensive to kill at least one of his enemies, which led him to death as a result of a fierce combat against Ashikaga soldiers, many of them had been killed at random by Chikamitsu, whereas one of them defeated him.
sen.cmt: 大友貞載「さだのり」および「さだとも」の読みがありますが、頻出の前者を採用しました。http://books.google.com/books?id=K9fBsIFIjLoC&pg=PA317&dq=Otomo+Sadanori&as_brr=3&hl=ja&cd=2#v=onepage&q=Otomo%20Sadanori&f=false
sen.e: "Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace, a Japanese military epic written in the late 14th century) shows as follows: When Sadanori OTOMO, who attended to Chikamitsu, asked why Chikamitsu, who gave up, didn't undress his armor, Chikamitsu thought Sadanori noticed his plot to assassinate Takauji then he killed Sadanori and some Ashikaga soldiers swarming on him at random, intending to kill as many of his enemies as possible, but was defeated by a Ashikaga soldier.

sen.j: 『梅松論』によれば、親光は貞載に斬りつけて重傷を負わせたが返り討ちにあって首を取られ、貞載もこの傷が元でまもなく死亡したとする。
sen.e: "The Baishoron" (literally, the argument about Japanese plum and pine; a Japanese historical epic written in the mid-fourteenth century) depicts the same episode of Chikamitsu's death as follows: Chikamitsu gave a fatal blow with his sword to Sadanori, who fought back to behead Chikamitsu before breathing his last.

sen.e: Alternatively, some believed that Chikamitsu targeted Sadanori but not Takauji, as Sadanori had betrayed the Imperial army and changed the side to the Ashikaga army during the Battle of Hakone and Takenoshita.

sen.j: 建武政権では親光と楠木正成、千種忠顕、名和長年を合わせて「三木一草」と併称した。
sen.e: Under the Kenmu regime, Chikamitsu YUKI, Masashige KUSUNOKI, Tadaaki CHIGUSA and Nagatoshi NAWA (the Governor of Hoki Province) were collectively called the "Sanboku Isso" (literally, the three trees [ki] and the single grass [kusa], implying part of the sound of each person's name or title.)
